column1: The name "Cebu" came from the old Cebuano word sibu or sibo ("trade")
column2: a shortened form of sinibuayng hingpit ("the place for trading"). It was originally applied to the harbors of the town of Sugbu
column3: the ancient name for Cebu City. Sugbu or Sugbo
column4: in turn
column5: was derived from the Old Cebuano term for "scorched earth" or "great fire".

column1: Before the arrival of the Spaniards
column2: Cebu city was part of the island-rajahnate and trade center of Pulua Kang Dayang or Kangdaya (literally "[the islands] which belong to Daya")
column3: now better known as the Rajahnate of Cebu. It was founded by a prince of the Hindu Chola dynasty of Sumatra
column4: the half-Malay and half-Tamil
column5: Sri Lumay. The name Sugbo (shortened form of Kang Sri Lumaying Sugbo
column6: literally "that of Sri Lumay's great fire") refers to Sri Lumay's scorched earth tactics against Muslim Pirates or Moro raiders (Magalos).

column3: Portuguese explorer Ferdinand Magellan landed in Cebu. He was welcomed by Rajah Humabon (also known as Sri Humabon or Rajah Humabara)

column6: however

column8: and the remaining members of his expedition left Cebu soon after several of them were poisoned by Humabon
column9: who was fearful of foreign occupation. The last ruler of Sugbo

column2: the Spanish settlement in Cebu had become important as a safe port for ships from Mexico and as a jumping-off point for further exploration of the archipelago. Small expeditions led by Juan de Salcedo went to Mindoro and Luzon
column3: where he and Martín de Goiti played a leading role in the subjugation of the Kingdoms of Tundun and Seludong in 1570. One year later
column4: López de Legazpi departed Cebu to discuss a peace pact with the defeated Rajahs. An agreement between the conquistadors and the Rajahs to form a city council paved the way for the establishment of a new settlement and the construction of the Christian walled city of Intramuros on the razed remains of Islamic Manila
column5: then a vassal-state of the Sultanate of Brunei.

column2: the Spanish carried over infantry from Mexico

column4: and assaulted the Sultanate of Brunei in what is known as the Castilian War. The war also started the Spanish–Moro Wars waged between the Christian Visayans and Muslim Mindanao
column5: wherein Moros burned towns and conducted slave raids in the Visayas islands and selling the slaves to the Sultanates of the Malay Archipelago and the Visayans fought back by establishing Christian fort-cities in Mindanao

column1: === American occupation and World War II ===

The signing of the Treaty of Paris at the end of the Spanish–American War provided for the cession of Cebu along with the rest of the Philippine islands to the United States until the formation of the Commonwealth Era (1935–46). On February 21
column3: the USS Petrel (PG-2) deployed a landing party of 40 marines on the shores of Cebu. Cebu's transfer to the American government was signed by Luis Flores although others
column4: most notably General Arcadio Maxilom and Juan Climaco
column5: offered resistance until 1901. Governor W. H. Taft visited Cebu on April 17
column7: and appointed Julio Llorento as the first provincial governor. Juan Climaco was elected to that office in January 1904.In 1934
column12: and San Nicolas were dissolved to be merged to the municipality of Cebu and become one of its barangays. After having remained a town since its original founding in 1565
column13: Cebu became a chartered city on February 24
column14: 1937. Many other Philippine cities such as Dansalan (now Marawi)
column16: and Bacolod were also incorporated at that time (see Cities of the Philippines).

column1: Along with the rest of the country
column2: Cebu came under Japanese occupation during World War II. The Japanese encountered some opposition there from guerrillas and irregular forces led by Col. James Cushing and the Cebu Area Command. It was finally liberated with the Battle for Cebu City in March and April 1945. The military general headquarters of the Philippine Commonwealth Army and 8th Constabulary Regiment of the Philippine Constabulary
column3: active from January 3
column4: 1942 to June 30
column6: was stationed in Cebu City during World War II.

column1: Cebu City has a land area of 315 square kilometres (122 sq mi). To the northeast of the city is Mandaue City and the town of Consolacion; to the west is Toledo City and the towns of Balamban and Asturias; to the south is Talisay City and the town of Minglanilla.
Across Mactan Strait to the east is Mactan island where Lapu-Lapu is located. Further east across the Cebu Strait is the island of Bohol.
The city comprises 80 barangays. These are grouped into two congressional districts
column2: with 46 barangays in the northern district and 34 in the southern district. The three most populous are Guadalupe (> 61
column4: Lahug (> 38
column6: and Tisa (> 37

column1: Cebu City has a tropical monsoon climate under the Köppen climate classification. The city has a lengthy wet season and a short dry season
column2: with only the months of March and April falling into the latter season. Average temperatures show little variance during the year with average daily temps ranging from 27 °C (81 °F) to 29 °C (84 °F). The city on averages experiences roughly 1
column3: 700 millimetres (67 in) of precipitation annually.

column2: Cebu City (along with neighboring Mandaue and Lapu-Lapu) is independent from Cebu province. Its electorate do not vote for provincial officials. There were proposals during the time of Governor Emilio Mario Osmeña to establish an "administrative district" that would be independent from Cebu City. This would mean carving out Cebu City's Capitol Site barangay
column3: where the provincial capitol and other provincial offices are located. The plan
column4: however
column5: did not go through and was even followed by other proposals like the transfer of the capital to Balamban.

column1: Cebu City is governed by a mayor
column2: vice mayor and sixteen councilors (eight representing the north and eight representing the south districts). Each official is popularly elected to serve for a three-year term. The chief of the Association of Barangay Captains and the president of the Sangguniang Kabataan Federation also serve in the city council. The day-to-day administration of the city is handled by a city administrator.

Cebu City is a significant cultural center in the Philippines. The imprint of Spanish and Roman Catholic culture is evident. The city's most famous landmark is Magellan's Cross. This cross
column2: now housed in a chapel
column3: is reputed to have been erected by Ferdinand Magellan (Fernão Magalhães) when he arrived in the Philippines in 1521. It was encased in hollow tindalo wood in 1835 upon the order of the Augustinian Bishop Santos Gómez Marañon to prevent devotees from taking it home chip by chip. The same bishop restored the present template or kiosk
column4: located at Magallanes Street between the City Hall and Colegio del Santo Niño. Revered by Filipinos
column5: the Magellan's Cross is a symbol of Christianity in the Philippines.

column1: A few steps away from Magellan's Cross is the Basilica Minore del Santo Niño (Church of the Holy Child). This is an Augustinian church elevated to the rank of basilica in 1965 during the 400th anniversary celebrations of Christianity in the Philippines
column2: held in Cebu. The church
column3: which was the first to be established in the islands
column4: is built of hewn stone and features the country's oldest relic
column5: the figure of the Santo Niño de Cebú (Holy Child of Cebu)
column6: who is Jesus Christ as a Child.

column1: This religious and cultural event is celebrated during the island's cultural festivities known as the Sinulog festival. Held every third Sunday of January
column2: it celebrates the festival of the Santo Niño
column3: who was formerly considered to be the patron saint of Cebu. (This patronage was later changed to that of Our Lady of Guadalupe after it was realised that the Santo Niño could not be a patron saint because he was an image of Christ and not a saint.) The Sinulog is a dance prayer ritual of pre-Hispanic indigenous origin. The dancer moves two steps forward and one step backward to the rhythmic sound of drums. This movement resembles somewhat the current (sulog) of the river. Thus
column4: the Cebuanos called it Sinulog.

column4: offered a baptismal gift to Hara Amihan
column5: wife of Rajah Humabon. She was later named Juana
column6: the figure of the Santo Niño. The natives also honored the Santo Niño de Cebú in their indigenous sinulog ritual. This ritual was preserved but limited to honoring the Santo Niño. Once the Santo Niño church was built in the 16th century
column7: the Christianized-Austronesian natives started performing the sinulog ritual in front of the church
column8: the devotees offering candles and indigenous dancers shouting "Viva Pit Señor!"In the 1980s and 2000s
column9: the city authorities of Cebu added the religious feast of Santo Niño de Cebú during the Sinulog Festival to its cultural event.

column1: The city is served by a domestic and international port which are handled by the Cebu Port Authority. The city is home to more than 80% of the country's island vessels traveling on domestic routes mostly in the Visayas and Mindanao.Transportation throughout the city and the metropolitan itself is provided by jeepneys
column2: buses and taxis. The Cebu City Government conducted a 2012 feasibility study on implementing bus rapid transit (BRT) system that will ease the transportation of the residents in the city and throughout the entire Metro Cebu area. Aimed to serve an estimated 330
column3: 000 passengers per day
column4: the project would have a capacity of 176 buses running through 33 stations along Bulacao until Talamban with a link to South Road Properties. The project is currently branded as TransCebu and is expected to be fully operational by 2017. As of March 2017 it is already two years late
